com.apriori.collections

Class TransformingMap<KI,VI,KO,VO>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.apriori.collections.TransformingMap<KI,VI,KO,VO>
  • Type Parameters:
    KI - the "input" key type; the type of keys in the wrapped map
    VI - the "input" value type; the type of values in the wrapped map
    KO - the "output" key type; the type of keys in this map
    VO - the "output" value type; the type of values in this map
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.util.Map<KO,VO>
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    TransformingMap.Bidi, TransformingMap.ReadOnly

    public class TransformingMap<KI,VI,KO,VO>
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.util.Map<KO,VO>
    A map whose keys and/or values are the results of applying functions to the keys and/or values of another map. This map is simply a wrapper. Changes to the underlying map are visible in the transformed set. Accessing the map's contents may incur calls to the transforming function.

    Functions that perform the transformations should be deterministic so that a stable, unchanging map does not appear to be mutating when accessed through this transforming wrapper.

    Since transformations can only be done in one direction, some operations are not supported. Namely, put(Object, Object) and putAll(Map) throw UnsupportedOperationException.

    Note: If keys are being transformed, the key function should produce a 1-to-1 mapping from elements of the input type to elements of the output type. If the function should ever produce the same output value for two unequal input values, then the invariant that is core to the map -- that its keys are unique -- could be broken for the transformed map. Failure to comply with this constraint may yield maps that appear to have duplicates. Because of this requirement, caution is advised when using a TransformingMap that transforms keys. A safer way to transform a map's keys is to make a snapshot that is transformed and dump those into a new map which can enforce uniqueness. That could be done with code like the following:

     Map<Type1, ValueType> input;
 Function<Type1, Type2> function;
 // take a snapshot to produce a transformed map that will never
 // violate map invariants
 Map<Type2, ValueType> transformed = new HashMap<>(
       TransformingMap.transformingKeys(input, function));

    Also maps with transformed keys (due to transformations only working in one direction) have some methods that are implemented in terms of the map's entry iterator and thus may have worse performance than the underlying map's implementation. These methods include get(Object), containsKey(Object) and remove(Object).

    See Also:
    TransformingMap.ReadOnly, TransformingMap.Bidi

      • transformingValues

        public static <K,VI,VO> TransformingMap<K,VI,K,VO> transformingValues(java.util.Map<K,VI> internal,
                                                                      java.util.function.Function<? super VI,? extends VO> function)
        Creates a transforming wrapper that only transforms map values. Since keys are not being transformed, the returned map is more efficient than one where keys are being transformed.
        Parameters:
        internal - the map being wrapped
        function - the function used to produce transformed map values
        Returns:
        a view of the given map, but with values transformed via the given function

      • transformingValues

        public static <K,VI,VO> TransformingMap<K,VI,K,VO> transformingValues(java.util.Map<K,VI> internal,
                                                                      java.util.function.BiFunction<? super K,? super VI,? extends VO> function)
        Creates a transforming wrapper that only transforms map values. Since keys are not being transformed, the returned map is more efficient than one where keys are being transformed.

        Some operations may pass a type other than K to the given two-argument function. In particular, get(Object) and remove(Object) will compute the transformed result using the given object as the key. This could result in ClassCastException being thrown in some cases. For example, if a map contained keys of type HashSet<T>, and the given function requires input keys to also be HashSet<T>. In this case, if the map is queried using a TreeSet<T>, a mapping could be found even though the key is the wrong type due to the specification for Set.equals(Object), and an exception could result.

        Parameters:
        internal - the map being wrapped
        function - a function used to produce transformed map values given both the original key and value as its inputs
        Returns:
        a view of the given map, but with values transformed via the given function
